text:
CHRISTINE LIU: I was scrolling
through LinkedIn today,

and I had to wonder, wait,
why am I on this platform?
You tell me.
What is this?
What am I doing here?
It is not really fun.

I see someone is
following another company.

But I'm on it every
day, all the time.
There's a sponsored ad.
Why though?

If you think about
it, LinkedIn is

this kind of dorky social media
cousin of all the platforms.

But it's where
you're professional

and you go to
connect and network

and maybe find things about jobs
and it's like a resume place.

I just have to ask myself,
am I doing this right?
Am I using LinkedIn properly?
[MUSIC PLAYING]

So when I look at my profile,
there's some thoughts.

I'm not reading
this super closely,
because I think I might--
[LAUGHS]
Read it out loud.
No, no.
It's too-- I can't read--
Read it out loud.
No.
OK.
"About Me.

I put all the people
and pieces in place

to produce stellar content
for deeply targeted audiences,

thereby growing and feeding an
engaged and loyal community.

I work best in deep
thinking, fast moving,
mission-driven teams."

That's the first
of four paragraphs.

How many experiences do I
have under my background?

OK, one, two, three,
15, 16, 17, 18, 19.

There's also more that
I didn't put on here.
I need help with LinkedIn.

I need to find an expert who
can answer all my questions.

Because I'm on it, but
clearly, I don't understand it.

MADELINE MANN:
LinkedIn is a place

where you reach second and third
degree connections and beyond

without having a
large following.

As far as if you're comparing
it to other platforms,

it is significantly easier
to gain traction on LinkedIn.

CHRISTINE LIU: This
is Madeline Mann.

She's a human resources
leader, and she's

the host of Self Made
Millennial on YouTube.

And she teaches personal
brand management

and thought leadership
techniques on LinkedIn.

A disclaimer, this is
not sponsored in any way
by LinkedIn.

First things first, why
should I even be on LinkedIn?

MADELINE MANN: LinkedIn is a
place for personal branding.

So it is a place to say here is
the value I add to the world.

And it makes you so
discoverable and connect

to people where in
times pre LinkedIn,

you would have never
been able to get
in contact with that person.

CHRISTINE LIU: I
think for most people,

LinkedIn is that place you go
when you're looking for a job
or you're hiring.

And that's certainly
the way I viewed it.

But Madeline
unsurprisingly disagrees.

MADELINE MANN: There are
people constantly scouring

LinkedIn wanting to
give you opportunities,

wanting to have you come
on their YouTube channel

or wanting to give
you your next job

or wanting to have you
be-- a lot of my students

have been expert
witnesses in trials,
like really cool opportunities.

And because LinkedIn
is a search engine,

you are missing out on
sitting on your butt,

watching TV, and having
opportunities come to you

without really any
outbound effort.

CHRISTINE LIU: I actually had
Madeline audit my profile.

How would this
thing look to a pro?
Give it to me straight.
MADELINE MANN: OK, sounds good.

The photo with the headline is
the true, most important parts

that you really
want to first get,

because those are
the things that are
going to make someone click.

The photos that perform
the best on LinkedIn,

that attract the
most opportunities,

are ones where you're looking
directly at the camera
and smiling.

CHRISTINE LIU: Madeleine
also strongly suggests

checking your privacy settings,
especially the visibility
of your profile photo.

You want it to be visible
to the public, not just

a subset or just
your connections.

MADELINE MANN: Your headline
is effective in saying
what you do currently.

But I would love to see a
few additional keywords.

Some keywords you could
add is the industry
you work in or maybe some--

maybe journalism would be
a word or something else
that pertains to what you do.

And then what I'd like to add
at the end is a unique value.

Maybe it could be that you
are the creator or the lead

of this programming
or something like that
that is really unique to you.

For your About section,
almost every sentence,

you want it to be
where it's impossible

that someone else could have
written it about themselves.

So instead of saying I work best
in deep thinking environments,

maybe say when I
was at x place, we

had a deep thinking
environment where

I was able to build
out this and that.

CHRISTINE LIU: How
many experiences do I
have under my background?
OK, one, two--
MADELINE MANN: Oh yeah.

You have to click several
times to get all the way--
oh my gosh.
And you keep going.
What an adventure.
OK, great.
I'm with you, Christine.

I have had at least
over 15 jobs in my life.

I deleted almost all of
them from my profile.

You want to tell a cohesive
narrative and a story.

CHRISTINE LIU: Madeline said my
profile overall wasn't too bad.

But there was, if anything,
just too much information.

And she told me that
the profile is not

there to tell your full story
but to tell your best story.
OK, I have a lot of work to do.

I've taken her advice, and I've
broken it into eight steps.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

One, I replaced
my photo with one

where I'm actually
looking at the camera.

And I'll also add a banner
image, something simple.
Two, I'll rewrite my headline.

Job title, company,
keyword about my industry,
and a specialty.

Three, be super specific
in the About Me section.

You want to write something
that not anyone could say,

so avoid cliches, I
work great in teams.

Four, you want to
craft your narrative.

You want to tell your
best story, not just
your full story.

Five, you want to post
at least once a week.

And when you do, try to draw
from your personal experiences

and maybe a little vulnerability
to spark discussion and others
to share.

Six, give, don't ask for,
but give recommendations.

Seven, review and update
your profile quarterly,

because your goals
or focus may change.
This is tough.

Being on LinkedIn is
about opportunities.

And if you're not there,
it's not going to hurt you,

but you may lose out
on those opportunities.
I'm exhausted, no lie.

Feels really good to
get this work done.

But I know I won't
see the results

or the huge transformation
for a while.
It's a long game.

I have a lot more
knowledge about this.

Hopefully you find
this helpful as well.

And maybe we can keep
each other accountable,

support each other,
give each other tips.
You knew this was coming.

You could follow me
on the old Link--
[BEEP]

If you're still
watching, one, thank you.

But two, I'm really curious,
what do you want me to explore?

What problems do
you have at work?
I'd love to solve them.
Please leave a comment.
I'd love to hear your thoughts.

And if you have any other
ideas, throw them my way.
All right.
Peace out.
